awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Energy Literacy through Place-based Learning: Using the School Building to Link Energy Use with Earth Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Student understanding of energy concepts about Earth systems and human-built systems require grappling with current societal issues related to resource use and management, energy sources, climate impacts, and sustainability. These relationships are challenging for students and underdeveloped in many science curriculum frameworks. This exploratory project will design, pilot, and evaluate a 10-weeek, energy literacy curriculum unit for a program called Energy and Your Environment (EYE). In the EYE curriculum, students will study energy use and transfer in their own school buildings. They will explore how Earth systems supply renewable and nonrenewable energy, and how these energy sources are transformed and transferred from Earth systems to a school building to meet its daily energy requirements. Learning about complex ideas in a place that is common to both students and teachers provides a means for deeper understanding and application of energy use and exchange. The research team includes researchers in biology and in architecture with an emphasis on natural resources and the environment. The researchers will work with four middle school science teachers to develop a curriculum unit that requires deep understanding of energy-systems models, but that will also be designed to apply to the school system and community. This is place-based learning aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards to foster energy literacy, modeling of energy use and flow, and systems thinking. 

The research questions for this study will ask about students' ability to construct and explain models about energy use and exchange, as well as about teachers’ use of the newly developed instructional materials. The research team will collaborate with 4 middle school teachers to design and test the unit in their classrooms. Data collection includes students' drawn models of the energy systems in use in their school building, student and teacher interviews, classroom observations, and teacher questionnaires. Student understanding of the learning goals will be assessed through a learning performance on energy modeling, and an accompanying rubric to score student models and explanations. After an initial implementation of the unit in classrooms, the following summer, researchers and teachers will meet to revise the curriculum materials. Then, teachers new to the curriculum unit will participate in the professional development required to teach the EYE unit. They will introduce the revised unit to their students in the next year, as researchers collect data and evaluate student learning for the revised curriculum materials. Overall, the project intends to include about 600 middle school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Enhancing Energy Literacy through Place-based Learning: The Energy in Your Environment (EYE) Project is an interdisciplinary project in which science education was taught through sustainable architecture. The project met two objectives. First, the project sought to support middle school students’ energy literacy through NGSS-aligned placed-based curriculum materials. The curriculum unit leveraged the physical built environment of the school building to foster deeper understanding of energy flows and the impact of human energy choices on our natural world. Buildings are a major factor in the overall story of how humans impact energy flow within Earth’s systems and offer an ideal venue for place-based energy education. The EYE unit weaves together the connections between Earth Systems and buildings to support learning about energy flow across systems. The unit thus supports systems thinking in middle school science learning while meeting the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) for energy and the impacts of human activities on Earth Systems. 

Development of the EYE unit was an iterative and collaborative effort with the interdisciplinary project team and five middle school science teachers. Within the granting period (2020 – 2024), the unit was developed in 2020 – 2021, and then tested over a two-year period with nearly 1,400 students in public middle school classrooms. In addition, in June of 2022 and July of 2024, the engineering module was tested during STEM outreach activities within the University of Missouri system with over 50 middle school aged students. 

The final EYE curricular unit contains four modules: 1) Energy systems, 2) Artificial and Natural Light, 3) Staying Warm and Cool, and 4) Engineering Design. Each module contains approximately 5 lessons for a total of 20 lessons across the unit. Engineering design is woven throughout the modules, where the unit culminates in an engineering design challenge to design an energy efficient one-room schoolhouse. The completed EYE unit is freely available to the public (located here). All student facing materials are also available in Spanish (located here).

 This project also engaged in exploratory research to investigate middle school students’ use of modeling to develop systems thinking practices for understanding energy flow between societal and Earth Systems. Students’ systems models created a means for them to consider the components of the system and how these components causally interact to form system behavior. The models serve as learning tools to help students to generate concrete representations of an abstract science concept (energy flow through systems). 

The results indicated that across the unit, students' consideration of relationships between societal system (buildings) and Earth systems significantly increased from pre to post assessments (Zangori, Snyder, Cole, Otto, & Fallahhosseini, 2024). Students demonstrated increased understanding of the human system (energy flow within the school building) and the natural system (natural resources that produce energy for the school building). A doctoral dissertation (Fallahhosseini, 2024) completed for the project additionally examined student agency in the engineering design process to illuminate ways that students navigated the team-based activity. 

In the grant extension year (2023 – 2024), the final revised unit served as the baseline unit for the NSF DRK12 #2201204 project called Build It Green! (BIG!). This new DRK12 grant evolves the EYE unit into a storyline unit that includes a suite of educational digital tools. These tools are designed to enhance student understanding of various energy flows within buildings. As the baseline unit, the EYE unit was additionaly taught in 22 rural participating teacher classrooms, reaching approximately 700 students nationwide, including Puerto Rico. This baseline data from EYE will be used to understand how educational digitial tools placed in the BIG unit further support middle school energy system learning. 

Overall, across the granting period (2020 – 2024), the unit was taught to over 2,100 students. In addition, results from the project have been shared through numerous outlets, including 12 conference presentations at the international, national, and state levels by the project team. The project has resulted in one book chapter, and two journal manuscripts that are currently under review. This project was also featured in media coverage, including local news broadcasts, online education outlets, and in print media. We estimate the media coverage had the potential to reach over 500,000 viewers.

EYE Unit, Spanish Translation of Student Materials: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/14C1Ee22y3cTuHu0D6g99V6Zs-FilwR7p 

Fallahhosseini, S. (2024). Investigation of middle school students' goal-driven agency use in the process of engineering design. [Unplublished doctoral dissertation]. University of Missouri, Columbia. 

Zangori, L., Snyder, R., Cole, L., Otto, S., Fallahhosseini, S., (2024, April 11 – 14). Development of a socio-ecological learning performance for middle school students’ ideas about energy flow. [Poster Session]. American Educational Research Association (AERA), Philadelphia, PA.
